revision.text:
{{Use dmy dates|date=June 2017}} {{Infobox Treaty | name = United Nations Convention on the Law of the Sea | long_name = | image = UNCLOS logo.png | caption = Logo of the Convention | date_drafted = | date_signed = 10 December 1982 | location_signed = [[Montego Bay]], Jamaica | date_sealed = | date_effective = 16 November 1994<ref name="history">{{cite web|url=https://www.un.org/Depts/los/convention_agreements/convention_historical_perspective.htm |title=The United Nations Convention on the Law of the Sea (A historical perspective) | publisher=United Nations Division for Ocean Affairs and the Law of the Sea| accessdate=30 April 2009}}</ref> | condition_effective = 60 ratifications | date_expiration = | signatories =157<ref name=rat>{{cite web|url=https://treaties.un.org/pages/ViewDetailsIII.aspx?src=TREATY&mtdsg_no=XXI-6&chapter=21&Temp=mtdsg3&clang=_en|title=United Nations Convention on the Law of the Sea|accessdate=1 December 2013|publisher=[[United Nations Treaty Series]]}}</ref> | parties = [[List of parties to the United Nations Convention on the Law of the Sea|168]]<ref name=rat/><ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.un.org/Depts/los/reference_files/chronological_lists_of_ratifications.htm | title=Chronological lists of ratifications of, accessions and successions to the Convention and the related Agreements| publisher=United Nations Division for Ocean Affairs and the Law of the Sea| date=8 January 2010 |accessdate=24 February 2010}}</ref> | depositor = [[Secretary-General of the United Nations]] | languages = Arabic, Chinese, English, French, Russian, and Spanish | website = | wikisource = United Nations Convention on the Law of the Sea }}
The '''United Nations Convention on the Law of the Sea''' ('''UNCLOS'''), also called the '''Law of the Sea Convention''' or the '''Law of the Sea treaty''', is the international agreement that resulted from the third United Nations Conference on the Law of the Sea (UNCLOS III), which took place between 1973 and 1982. The Law of the Sea Convention defines the rights and responsibilities of nations with respect to their use of the world's oceans, establishing guidelines for businesses, the environment, and the management of marine [[natural resource]]s. The Convention, concluded in 1982, replaced four 1958 [[treaties]]. UNCLOS came into force in 1994, a year after Guyana became the 60th nation to ratify the treaty.<ref name="history"/> {{As of|2016|06}}, 167 countries and the [[European Union]] have joined in the Convention. It is uncertain as to what extent the Convention codifies [[customary international law]].
While the [[Secretary-General of the United Nations]] receives instruments of [[ratification]] and accession and the UN provides support for meetings of states party to the Convention, the UN has no direct operational role in the implementation of the Convention. There is, however, a role played by organizations such as the [[International Maritime Organization]], the [[International Whaling Commission]], and the [[International Seabed Authority|International Seabed Authority (ISA)]]. (The ISA was established by the UN Convention.)
==Background== UNCLOS replaces the older '[[freedom of the seas]]' concept, dating from the 17th century: national rights were limited to a specified belt of water extending from a nation's [[coast]]lines, usually {{convert|3|nmi|km}} ([[Three-mile limit]]), according to the '[[cannon]] shot' rule developed by the Dutch jurist [[Cornelius van Bynkershoek]].<ref name="Akashi-Bynkershoek">{{cite book|last1=Akashi|first1=Kinji|title=Cornelius Van Bynkershoek: His Role in the History of International Law|date=2 October 1998|publisher=Martinus Nijhoff Publishers|isbn=978-9041105998|page=150|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=8Pp--yPYL58C&lpg=PA150&ots=qgJPsX3-ZM&dq=Cornelius%20van%20Bynkershoek%20cannon&pg=PA150#v=onepage&q=Cornelius%20van%20Bynkershoek%20cannon&f=false|accessdate=12 July 2016|ref=Akashi-Bynkershoek}}</ref> All waters beyond national boundaries were considered [[international waters]]: free to all nations, but belonging to none of them (the ''[[International waters|mare liberum]]'' principle promulgated by [[Hugo Grotius]]).<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://oll.libertyfund.org/titles/grotius-the-freedom-of-the-seas-latin-and-english-version-magoffin-trans|title=The Freedom of the Seas (Latin and English version, Magoffin trans.) – Online Library of Liberty|website=oll.libertyfund.org|access-date=27 January 2017}}</ref>
In the early 20th century, some nations expressed their desire to extend national claims: to include mineral resources, to protect [[fish stock]]s, and to provide the means to enforce [[Pollution#Pollution control|pollution controls]]. (The [[League of Nations]] called a 1930 conference at [[The Hague]], but no agreements resulted.) Using the customary international law principle of a nation's right to protect its natural resources, President [[Harry S. Truman]] in 1945 extended United States control to all the natural resources of its [[continental shelf]]. Other nations were quick to follow suit. Between 1946 and 1950, Chile, Peru, and Ecuador extended their rights to a distance of {{convert|200|nmi|km}} to cover their [[Humboldt Current]] fishing grounds. Other nations extended their territorial seas to {{convert|12|nmi|km}}.{{citation needed|date=March 2016}}
By 1967, only 25 nations still used the old {{convert|3|mi|km|adj=on}} limit,{{citation needed|date=March 2016}} while 66 nations had set a {{convert|12|nmi|km|adj=on}} territorial limit{{citation needed|date=March 2016}} and eight had set a {{convert|200|nmi|km|adj=on}} limit.{{citation needed|date=March 2016}} {{As of|2008|05|28}}, only two countries still use the {{convert|3|mi|km|adj=on}} limit: Jordan and Palau.<ref name="untableofclaims">{{cite web | title=Table of claims to maritime jurisdiction | url=https://www.un.org/Depts/los/LEGISLATIONANDTREATIES/PDFFILES/table_summary_of_claims.pdf | accessdate=1 May 2009 | publisher=United Nations Division for Ocean Affairs and the Law of the Sea}}</ref> That limit is also used in certain Australian islands, an area of Belize, some Japanese [[strait]]s, certain areas of Papua New Guinea, and a few [[British Overseas Territories]], such as [[Anguilla]].{{citation needed|date=March 2016}}
== UNCLOS I == {| class="gaga" style="text-align:center; margin-left:10px" align="right" border="1" |+ Territorial waters claims by coastal states in 1960<ref name=mlr82-behuniak>{{cite journal |url=https://www.jagcnet.army.mil/DOCLIBS/MILITARYLAWREVIEW.NSF/20a66345129fe3d885256e5b00571830/b3197adca4437e4d85256e5b0057ee6a/$FILE/MLR%2027-100-82%2019781001.pdf |title=The Seizure and Recovery of the S.S. Mayaguez: Legal Analysis of United States Claims, Part 1 |author=Major Thomas E. Behuniak |journal=Military Law Review |volume=82 |publisher=Department of the Army |year=Fall 1978 |issn=0026-4040 |pages=114–121 |accessdate=21 July 2014 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20161228203240/https://www.jagcnet.army.mil/DOCLIBS/MILITARYLAWREVIEW.NSF/20a66345129fe3d885256e5b00571830/b3197adca4437e4d85256e5b0057ee6a/$FILE/MLR%2027-100-82%2019781001.pdf |archivedate=28 December 2016 |df=dmy-all }}</ref> |- ! style="background-color:#cfb" | Breadth claim !! style="background-color:#cfb" | Number of states |- | 3-mile limit || 26 |- | 4-mile limit || 3 |- | 5-mile limit || 1 |- | 6-mile limit || 16 |- | 9-mile limit || 1 |- | 10-mile limit || 2 |- | 12-mile limit || 34 |- | More than 12-miles || 9 |- | Unspecified || 11 |} In 1956, the United Nations held its first Conference on the Law of the Sea (UNCLOS I) at [[Geneva]], Switzerland. UNCLOS I<ref>[http://legal.un.org/ilc/texts/8_1.htm UNCLOS I]</ref> resulted in four treaties concluded in 1958:
* [[Convention on the Territorial Sea and Contiguous Zone]], entry into force: 10 September 1964 * [[Convention on the Continental Shelf]], entry into force: 10 June 1964 * [[Convention on the High Seas]], entry into force: 30 September 1962 * [[Convention on Fishing and Conservation of Living Resources of the High Seas]], entry into force: 20 March 1966
Although UNCLOS I was considered a success, it left open the important issue of breadth of territorial waters.<ref name=mlr82-behuniak/>
== UNCLOS II ==
In 1960, the United Nations held the second Conference on the Law of the Sea ("UNCLOS II"); however, the six-week Geneva conference did not result in any new agreements.<ref name=mlr82-behuniak/> Generally speaking, developing nations and third world countries participated only as clients, allies, or dependents of the United States or the Soviet Union, with no significant voice of their own.{{citation needed|date=November 2013}}
== UNCLOS III == [[File:Zonmar-en.svg|thumb|300px|Sea areas in international rights]]
The issue of varying claims of territorial waters was raised in the UN in 1967 by [[Arvid Pardo]] of Malta, and in 1973 the ''Third United Nations Conference on the Law of the Sea'' was convened in New York. In an attempt to reduce the possibility of groups of nation-states dominating the negotiations, the conference used a consensus process rather than majority vote. With more than 160 nations participating, the conference lasted until 1982. The resulting convention came into force on 16 November 1994, one year after the 60th state, Guyana, ratified the treaty.
The convention introduced a number of provisions. The most significant issues covered were setting limits, navigation, archipelagic status and transit regimes, [[exclusive economic zones]] (EEZs), continental shelf jurisdiction, deep seabed mining, the exploitation regime, protection of the marine environment, scientific research, and settlement of disputes.
The convention set the limit of various areas, measured from a carefully defined [[baseline (sea)|baseline]]. (Normally, a sea baseline follows the low-water line, but when the coastline is deeply indented, has fringing islands or is highly unstable, straight baselines may be used.) The areas are as follows:
; [[Internal waters]]:Covers all water and waterways on the landward side of the baseline. The coastal state is free to set laws, regulate use, and use any resource. Foreign vessels have no right of passage within internal waters. A vessel in the high seas assumes jurisdiction under the internal laws of its flag State. Pursuit of a ship by the Coastal State may only take place in the internal waters and is required to end when reaching the contiguous zone. ; [[Territorial waters]]: Out to {{convert|12|nmi|km mi|abbr=off}} from the baseline, the coastal state is free to set laws, regulate use, and use any resource. Vessels were given the right of [[innocent passage]] through any territorial waters, with strategic straits allowing the passage of military craft as [[transit passage]], in that naval vessels are allowed to maintain postures that would be illegal in territorial waters. "Innocent passage" is defined by the convention as passing through waters in an expeditious and continuous manner, which is not "prejudicial to the peace, good order or the security" of the coastal state. Fishing, polluting, weapons practice, and spying are not "innocent", and submarines and other underwater vehicles are required to navigate on the surface and to show their flag. Nations can also temporarily suspend innocent passage in specific areas of their territorial seas, if doing so is essential for the protection of their security. ; Archipelagic waters: The convention set the definition of Archipelagic States in Part IV, which also defines how the state can draw its territorial borders. A baseline is drawn between the outermost points of the outermost islands, subject to these points being sufficiently close to one another. All waters inside this baseline are designated ''Archipelagic Waters''. The state has sovereignty over these waters (like internal waters), but subject to existing rights including traditional fishing rights of immediately adjacent states.<ref name="UNCLOS3">{{cite web | url=https://www.un.org/depts/los/convention_agreements/texts/unclos/closindx.htm | title=UNCLOS 3 Article 51 | publisher=United Nations Division for Ocean Affairs and Law of the Sea | accessdate=29 March 2016}}</ref> Foreign vessels have right of innocent passage through archipelagic waters (like territorial waters). ; [[Contiguous zone]]: Beyond the {{convert|12|nmi|km|adj=on}} limit, there is a further {{convert|12|nmi|km}} from the territorial sea [[baseline (sea)|baseline]] limit, the contiguous zone, in which a state can continue to enforce laws in four specific areas: customs, taxation, immigration and pollution, if the infringement started within the state's territory or territorial waters, or if this infringement is about to occur within the state's territory or territorial waters.<ref>{{cite web|title=SECTION 4. CONTIGUOUS ZONE, Article 33|url=https://www.un.org/depts/los/convention_agreements/texts/unclos/part2.htm|work=UNCLOS PART II – TERRITORIAL SEA AND CONTIGUOUS ZONE|publisher=United Nations|accessdate=19 January 2012}}</ref> This makes the contiguous zone a [[hot pursuit]] area. ; [[Exclusive economic zone]]s (EEZs): These extend {{convert|200|nmi|km mi|abbr=off}} from the [[baseline (sea)|baseline]]. Within this area, the coastal nation has sole exploitation rights over all natural resources. In casual use, the term may include the territorial sea and even the continental shelf. The EEZs were introduced to halt the increasingly heated clashes over fishing rights, although [[Petroleum|oil]] was also becoming important. The success of an offshore [[oil platform]] in the [[Gulf of Mexico]] in 1947 was soon repeated elsewhere in the world, and by 1970 it was technically feasible to operate in waters 4,000 metres deep. Foreign nations have the freedom of navigation and overflight, subject to the regulation of the coastal states. Foreign states may also lay submarine pipes and cables. ; [[Continental shelf]]: The continental shelf is defined as the [[natural prolongation]] of the land territory to the [[continental margin]]'s outer edge, or {{convert|200|nmi|km}} from the coastal state's baseline, whichever is greater. A state's continental shelf may exceed {{convert|200|nmi|km}} until the natural prolongation ends. However, it may never exceed {{convert|350|nmi|km mi|abbr=off}} from the baseline; or it may never exceed {{convert|100|nmi|km mi|abbr=off}} beyond the 2,500-meter [[isobath]] (the line connecting the depth of 2,500 meters). Coastal states have the right to harvest mineral and non-living material in the subsoil of its continental shelf, to the exclusion of others. Coastal states also have exclusive control over living resources "attached" to the continental shelf, but not to creatures living in the water column beyond the exclusive economic zone.
Aside from its provisions defining ocean boundaries, the convention establishes general obligations for safeguarding the marine environment and protecting freedom of scientific research on the high seas, and also creates an innovative legal regime for controlling mineral resource exploitation in deep seabed areas beyond national jurisdiction, through an [[International Seabed Authority]] and the [[Common heritage of mankind]] principle.<ref>Jennifer Frakes, The Common Heritage of Mankind Principle and the Deep Seabed, Outer Space, and Antarctica: Will Developed and Developing Nations Reach a Compromise? Wisconsin International Law Journal. 2003; 21:409</ref>
[[Landlocked country|Landlocked]] states are given a right of access to and from the sea, without taxation of traffic through transit states.<ref>This is a principle that was first developed in the [[Convention on Transit Trade of Land-locked States]].</ref>
== Part XI and the 1994 Agreement ==
Part XI of the Convention provides for a regime relating to minerals on the seabed outside any state's territorial waters or EEZ (Exclusive Economic Zones). It establishes an [[International Seabed Authority]] (ISA) to authorize seabed exploration and mining and collect and distribute the seabed mining royalty.
The United States objected to the provisions of Part XI of the Convention on several grounds, arguing that the treaty was unfavorable to American economic and security interests. Due to Part XI, the United States refused to ratify the UNCLOS, although it expressed agreement with the remaining provisions of the Convention.
From 1982 to 1990, the United States accepted all but Part XI as customary international law, while attempting to establish an alternative regime for exploitation of the minerals of the deep seabed. An agreement was made with other seabed mining nations and licenses were granted to four international consortia. Concurrently, the Preparatory Commission was established to prepare for the eventual coming into force of the Convention-recognized claims by applicants, sponsored by signatories of the Convention. Overlaps between the two groups were resolved, but a decline in the demand for minerals from the seabed made the seabed regime significantly less relevant. In addition, the decline of Socialism and the fall of Communism in the late 1980s had removed much of the support for some of the more contentious Part XI provisions.
In 1990, consultations were begun between signatories and non-signatories (including the United States) over the possibility of modifying the Convention to allow the industrialized countries to join the Convention. The resulting 1994 Agreement on Implementation was adopted as a binding international Convention. It mandated that key articles, including those on limitation of seabed production and mandatory technology transfer, would not be applied, that the United States, if it became a member, would be guaranteed a seat on the Council of the International Seabed Authority, and finally, that voting would be done in groups, with each group able to block decisions on substantive matters. The 1994 Agreement also established a Finance Committee that would originate the financial decisions of the Authority, to which the largest donors would automatically be members and in which decisions would be made by consensus.
On 1 February 2011, the Seabed Disputes Chamber of the International Tribunal for the Law of the Sea (ITLOS) issued an advisory opinion concerning the legal responsibilities and obligations of States Parties to the Convention with respect to the sponsorship of activities in the Area in accordance with Part XI of the Convention and the 1994 Agreement.<ref>[http://www.itlos.org/fileadmin/itlos/documents/cases/case_no_17/adv_op_010211.pdf Case No. 17 – Responsibilities and Obligations of States Sponsoring Persons and Entities With Respect to Activities in the Area – Advisory Opinion], Seabed Disputes Chamber of the International Tribunal for the Law of the Sea (1 February 2011)</ref> The advisory opinion was issued in response to a formal request made by the International Seabed Authority following two prior applications the Authority's Legal and Technical Commission had received from the Republics of Nauru and Tonga regarding proposed activities (a plan of work to explore for polymetallic nodules) to be undertaken in the Area by two State-sponsored contractors – Nauru Ocean Resources Inc. (sponsored by the Republic of Nauru) and Tonga Offshore Mining Ltd. (sponsored by the Kingdom of Tonga). The advisory opinion set forth the international legal responsibilities and obligations of Sponsoring States AND the Authority to ensure that sponsored activities do not harm the marine environment, consistent with the applicable provisions of UNCLOS Part XI, Authority regulations, ITLOS case law, other international environmental treaties, and Principle 15 of the UN Rio Declaration.<ref>[http://itssdjournalunclos-lost.blogspot.com/2011/03/international-tribunal-on-law-of-sea.html International Tribunal on the Law of the Sea Finally Renders Advisory Opinion Establishing that the Precautionary Principle is Incorporated Within UNCLOS Law], ''ITSSD Journal on the UN Law of the Sea Convention'' (22 March 2011)</ref>
== Parties == {{main|List of parties to the United Nations Convention on the Law of the Sea}}
[[File:United Nations Convention on the Law of the Sea parties.svg|thumb|500px|right|{{legend|#92c5de|Parties}} {{legend|#0571b0|Parties, dually represented by the [[European Union]]}} {{legend|#f4a582|Signatories}} {{legend|#ca0020|Non-parties}}]]
The convention was opened for signature on 10 December 1982 and entered into force on 16 November 1994 upon deposition of the 60th instrument of ratification.<ref name="history"/> The convention has been ratified by 168 parties, which includes 167 states (164 member states of the United Nations plus the [[United Nations General Assembly observers|UN Observer state]] [[State of Palestine|Palestine]], as well as the [[Cook Islands]], [[Niue]] and the [[European Union]]).<ref name=rat/>
== See also == {{International ownership conventions}} {{Portal|Nautical|United Nations}} * [[Automatic Identification System]] * [[Admiralty law]] * [[Fisheries management]] * [[International Tribunal for the Law of the Sea]] * [[Law of salvage]] * [[Legal assessments of the Gaza flotilla raid]] * [[Maritime Security Regimes]] * [[Montreux Convention Regarding the Regime of the Turkish Straits]] * [[Operation Sharp Guard]] * [[Territorial waters]] * ''[[The Law of Cyber-Space]]'' * [[United States non-ratification of the UNCLOS]] * [[USA/USSR Joint Statement on Uniform Acceptance of Rules of International Law Governing Innocent Passage]] * [[United Nations General Assembly resolution]]

revision.text:
[[File:USA National Forests Map.jpg|300px|thumb|right|Locations of United States National Grasslands depicted in yellow]] [[File:Buffalo_Gap_National_Grassland_sign.JPG|300px|thumb|Entrance sign of a United States National Grassland area in South Dakota]] '''National Grassland''' is a classification of [[protected area|protected]] and managed [[federal lands]] in the United States authorized by Title III of the [[Bankhead–Jones Farm Tenant Act of 1937]]. For administrative purposes, they are essentially identical to [[United States National Forest]]s, except that grasslands are areas primarily consisting of [[prairie]]. Like National Forests, National Grasslands may be open for hunting, grazing, mineral extraction, recreation and other uses. Various National Grasslands are typically administered in conjunction with nearby National Forests. All but three National Grasslands are on or at the edge of the [[Great Plains]]. Those three are in southeastern [[Idaho]], northeastern [[California]], and central [[Oregon]]. The three National Grasslands in [[North Dakota]], together with one in northwestern South Dakota, are administered jointly as the [[Dakota Prairie Grasslands]]. National Grasslands are generally much smaller than National Forests. Whereas a typical National Forest would be about {{convert|1000000|acre|ha}}, the average Grassland size is {{convert|191914|acre|ha}}. The largest National Grassland, the [[Little Missouri National Grassland]] in North Dakota, covers {{convert|1028784|acre|ha}}, which is approximately the [[median]] size of a National Forest. As of September 30, 2007, the total area of all 20 National Grasslands was {{convert|3838280|acre|ha}}. ==Dust Bowl== The catastrophic [[Dust Bowl]] of the 1930s led to the creation of the [[Soil Conservation Service]] in 1933. This and subsequent federal laws paved the way for establishing national grasslands. ==List of National Grasslands== {| class="wikitable sortable plainrowheaders" style="width:98%" !scope="col" |Name !scope="col" class="unsortable"|Photo !scope="col" |Location{{cite web |title=U.S. Board on Geographic Names |publisher=[[U.S. Geological Survey]] |url=http://geonames.usgs.gov/ |accessdate=December 21, 2012}} !scope="col" |Administered by !scope="col" |Area{{Cite document |title=Land Areas of the National Forest System |publisher=U.S. Forest Service |date=January 2013 |url=http://www.fs.fed.us/land/staff/lar/index.html |accessdate=December 21, 2012 |postscript=.}} !scope="col" class="unsortable"|Description |- !scope="row" | [[Black Kettle National Grassland|Black Kettle]] |[[File:Black Kettle National Grassland.jpg|150px]] |[[Oklahoma]], [[Texas]]
{{coord|35|41|01|N|99|45|47|W|name=Black Kettle|type:landmark}} |[[Cibola National Forest]] |{{convert|31286|acre|km2|1|sortable=on}} |Black Kettle has sandy red slate hills as well as grassland and oak brush. There are three developed recreation areas, and the [[Washita River]] flows through the grassland. |- !scope="row" | [[Buffalo Gap National Grassland|Buffalo Gap]] |[[File:Buffalogap Charon.jpg|150px]] |[[South Dakota]]
{{coord|43|26|15|N|103|03|02|W|name=Buffalo Gap|type:landmark}} |[[Nebraska National Forest]]s |{{convert|595715|acre|km2|1|sortable=on}} |There are mixed prairie and [[badlands]] in Buffalo Gap as well as a reintroduced population of [[black-footed ferret]]s. |- !scope="row" | [[Butte Valley National Grassland|Butte Valley]] |[[File:ButteValley twotrees.jpg|150px]] |[[California]]
{{coord|41|53|57|N|122|01|31|W|name=Butte Valley|type:landmark}} |[[Klamath National Forest]] |{{convert|18425|acre|km2|1|sortable=on}} |Formed July 1991, Butte Valley is the most recent National Grassland. It contains [[Meiss Lake]] and views of the [[Cascade Range]]. |- !scope="row" | [[Caddo National Grassland|Caddo]] |[[File:Caddo NG red oak.jpg|150px]] |[[Texas]]
{{coord|33|43|56|N|95|57|29|W|name=Caddo|type:landmark}} |National Forests and Grasslands in Texas |{{convert|17873|acre|km2|1|sortable=on}} |Caddo is divided into two units and has two developed recreation areas around Lake Davy Crockett. |- !scope="row" | [[Cedar River National Grassland|Cedar River]] |[[File:Cedar River National Grassland.jpg|150px]] |[[North Dakota]]
{{coord|45|57|19|N|101|48|24|W|name=Cedar River|type:landmark}} |[[Dakota Prairie Grasslands]] |{{convert|6717|acre|km2|1|sortable=on}} |Cedar River is within the [[Standing Rock Indian Reservation]] and has rolling hills and ephemeral streams. |- !scope="row" | [[Cimarron National Grassland|Cimarron]] |[[File:Cimarron grassland.jpg|150px]] |[[Kansas]]
{{coord|37|08|18|N|101|46|56|W|name=Cimarron|type:landmark}} |[[Pike National Forest|Pike]] & [[San Isabel National Forest|San Isabel]] National Forests |{{convert|108176|acre|km2|1|sortable=on}} |Cimarron has shortgrass prairie with cottonwood groves along the [[Cimarron River (Arkansas River)|Cimarron River]]. |- !scope="row" | [[Comanche National Grassland|Comanche]] |[[File:Picture Canyon.jpg|150px]] |[[Colorado]]
{{coord|37|20|12|N|103|04|26|W|name=Comanche|type:landmark}} |[[Pike National Forest|Pike]] & [[San Isabel National Forest|San Isabel]] National Forests |{{convert|443081|acre|km2|1|sortable=on}} |There are not only prairies in Comanche, but also canyons, including [[Picture Canyon (Colorado)|Picture Canyon]]. |- !scope="row" | [[Crooked River National Grassland|Crooked River]] |[[File:Crooked River National Grassland.jpg|150px]] |[[Oregon]]
{{coord|44|32|36|N|121|06|34|W|name=Crooked River|type:landmark}} |[[Deschutes National Forest|Deschutes]] & [[Ochoco National Forest|Ochoco]] National Forests |{{convert|112357|acre|km2|1|sortable=on}} |Crooked River contains two [[National Wild and Scenic River]]s: the [[Deschutes River (Oregon)|Deschutes]] and [[Crooked River (Oregon)|Crooked]] rivers. |- !scope="row" | [[Curlew National Grassland|Curlew]] |[[File:Mule Deer Curlew.jpg|150px]] |[[Idaho]]
{{coord|42|11|15|N|112|41|57|W|name=Curlew|type:landmark}} |[[Caribou-Targhee National Forest]] |{{convert|47790|acre|km2|1|sortable=on}} |In southern Idaho, Curlew provides habitat for [[sage grouse]] while the Sweeten Pond area supports waterfowl and shorebirds. |- !scope="row" | [[Fort Pierre National Grassland|Fort Pierre]] |[[File:Fort Pierre Grassland pond.jpg|150px]] |[[South Dakota]]
{{coord|44|08|27|N|100|16|45|W|name=Fort Pierre|type:landmark}} |[[Nebraska National Forest]]s |{{convert|115890|acre|km2|1|sortable=on}} |Located north of [[Pierre, South Dakota]], Fort Pierre includes several ponds open to fishing and dispersed camping. |- !scope="row" | [[Grand River National Grassland|Grand River]] |[[File:Grand River NG Lone Tree.jpg|150px]] |[[South Dakota]]
{{coord|45|44|09|N|102|21|40|W|name=Grand River|type:landmark}} |[[Dakota Prairie Grasslands]] |{{convert|154783|acre|km2|1|sortable=on}} |In addition to prairie, there are a variety of habitats in Grand River, including sand dunes, river bottoms, [[badland]]s, [[butte]]s, and sandstone outcroppings. |- !scope="row" | [[Kiowa National Grassland|Kiowa]] |[[File:Kiowa range unit 53.jpg|150px]] |[[New Mexico]]
{{coord|36|10|00|N|104|10|02|W|name=Kiowa|type:landmark}} |[[Cibola National Forest]] |{{convert|137131|acre|km2|1|sortable=on}} |Kiowa consists of two units in northeastern New Mexico and includes canyons along the [[Canadian River]]. |- !scope="row" | [[Little Missouri National Grassland|Little Missouri]] |[[File:Little Missouri National Grasslands.jpg|150px]] |[[North Dakota]]
{{coord|47|05|55|N|103|32|14|W|name=Little Missouri|type:landmark}} |[[Dakota Prairie Grasslands]] |{{convert|1028784|acre|km2|1|sortable=on}} |The largest National Grassland, Little Missouri includes [[badland]]s and short and long grass prairie. |- !scope="row" | [[Lyndon B. Johnson National Grassland|Lyndon B. Johnson]] |[[File:LBJ Grasslands Hillside.jpg|150px]] |[[Texas]]
{{coord|33|20|56|N|97|39|32|W|name=NAME|type:landmark}} |National Forests and Grasslands in Texas |{{convert|20309|acre|km2|1|sortable=on}} |Used primarily for recreation, Lyndon B. Johnson National Grassland has no fees and is located northwest of [[Fort Worth, Texas|Fort Worth]]. |- !scope="row" | [[McClellan Creek National Grassland|McClellan Creek]] |[[File:Lake McClellan.jpg|150px]] |[[Texas]]
{{coord|35|12|42|N|100|52|16|W|name=McClellan Creek|type:landmark}} |[[Cibola National Forest]] |{{convert|1449|acre|km2|1|sortable=on}} |McClellan Creek National Grassland surrounds Lake McClellan, and nearly all of the grassland was burned in 2006. |- !scope="row" | [[Oglala National Grassland|Oglala]] |[[File:Oglala National Grassland.jpg|150px]] |[[Nebraska]]
{{coord|42|54|56|N|103|38|14|W|name=Oglala|type:landmark}} |[[Nebraska National Forest]]s |{{convert|94520|acre|km2|1|sortable=on}} |The [[badland]]s of [[Toadstool Geologic Park]] are within Oglala National Grassland. |- !scope="row" | [[Pawnee National Grassland|Pawnee]] |[[File:Pawnee Buttes2010.jpg|150px]] |[[Colorado]]
{{coord|40|47|38|N|104|05|01|W|name=Pawnee|type:landmark}} |[[Arapaho National Forest|Arapaho]] & [[Roosevelt National Forest|Roosevelt]] National Forests |{{convert|193060|acre|km2|1|sortable=on}} |Pawnee has camping at Crow Valley Recreation Area and trails to the [[Pawnee Buttes]]. |- !scope="row" | [[Rita Blanca National Grassland|Rita Blanca]] |[[File:Rita Blanca National Grassland.jpg|150px]] |[[Texas]], [[Oklahoma]]
{{coord|36|26|04|N|102|36|01|W|name=Rita Blanca|type:landmark}} |[[Cibola National Forest]] |{{convert|92989|acre|km2|1|sortable=on}} |Rita Blanca includes grasslands, marshes, and woodlands and is located in the [[Texas Panhandle]] and western Oklahoma. |- !scope="row" | [[Sheyenne National Grassland|Sheyenne]] |[[File:Sheyenne National Grassland.jpg|150px]] |[[North Dakota]]
{{coord|46|25|36|N|97|17|43|W|name=Sheyenne|type:landmark}} |[[Dakota Prairie Grasslands]] |{{convert|70446|acre|km2|1|sortable=on}} |Sheyenne provides habitat for the largest population of [[greater prairie chicken]]s in North Dakota as well as the [[Dakota skipper]] butterfly and [[western prairie fringed orchid]]. |- !scope="row" | [[Thunder Basin National Grassland|Thunder Basin]] |[[File:Thunder Basin National Grassland Douglas.jpg|150px]] |[[Wyoming]]
{{coord|43|41|09|N|105|00|56|W|name=Thunder Basin|type:landmark}} |[[Medicine Bow – Routt National Forest|Medicine Bow – Routt]] National Forest |{{convert|547499|acre|km2|1|sortable=on}} |Thunder Basin is located in the [[Powder River Basin]] between the [[Big Horn Mountains]] and the [[Black Hills]]. |- |} ==List of Prairie Reserves== {| class="wikitable sortable plainrowheaders" style="width:98%" !scope="col" |Name !scope="col" class="unsortable"|Photo !scope="col" |Location{{cite gnis|1802385|Midewin National Tallgrass Prairie|December 22, 2012}} !scope="col" |Date formed !scope="col" |Area !scope="col" class="unsortable"|Description |- !scope="row" | [[Midewin National Tallgrass Prairie]] |[[File:Midewin3.JPG|150px]] |[[Illinois]]
{{coord|41|22|44|N|88|06|46|W|name=NAME|type:landmark}} |{{dts|1996}} |{{convert|18226|acre|km2|1|sortable=on}} |The only federally managed prairie east of the [[Mississippi River]], Midewin is in the [[Central forest-grasslands transition]] [[ecoregion]] and was created when land was transferred to the U.S. Forest Service from the [[U.S. Army]]. It is open to non-motorized recreation. In 2015, a small research herd of [[American Bison]] were reintroduced to study the effect of this large prairie animal on [[tallgrass prairie]] regeneration. |} ==See also== {{kml}} * [[Grassland]] * [[Prairie]] * [[Temperate grasslands, savannas, and shrublands]] * [[List of U.S. National Forests]] * [[Wilderness preservation systems in the United States]] ==External links== {{Commons category|National Grasslands of the United States|position=left}} ==References== {{reflist}} {{US Protected Areas}} [[Category:National Grasslands of the United States| 01]] [[Category:Grasslands of the United States|*]] [[Category:Prairies]] [[Category:United States Forest Service protected areas|*Grasslands]] [[Category:Lists of protected areas of the United States|Grassland]] [[Category:1930s establishments in the United States]]

revision.text:
The '''Western Pacific Naval Symposium''' are a series of biennial meetings of the Pacific nations to discuss naval matters held on even numbered years. A WPNS workshop is held on odd numbered years in between the symposiums.<ref>[http://www.navy.mi.th/wpns2013/ WPNS WORKSHOP 2013]</ref>
==History== At the [[International Seapower Symposium]] in 1987 agreement was reached "to establish a forum where leaders of regional navies could meet to discuss cooperative initiatives". The first meeting was held in 1988.<ref>{{cite news |url=http://www.mindef.gov.sg/imindef/press_room/official_releases/nr/2011/mar/25mar11_nr/25mar11_fs.html |title=Fact Sheet: Background of the Western Pacific Naval Symposium, MCMEX, DIVEX and NMS |date=25 March 2011 |website=www.mindef.gov.sg |publisher=[[Ministry of Defence (Singapore)]] |accessdate=17 May 2015}}</ref>
Member countries as of 2010: Australia, Brunei, Cambodia, Canada, Chile, France, Indonesia, Japan, Malaysia, New Zealand, Papua New Guinea, People's Republic of China, Philippines, Republic of Korea, Russia, Singapore, Thailand, Tonga, United States of America, Vietnam. Observers: Bangladesh, India, Mexico, Peru, The United Kingdom. <ref>https://www.mindef.gov.sg/imindef/press_room/official_releases/nr/2011/mar/25mar11_nr/25mar11_fs.html</ref>
At the 2014 WPNS, agreement was reached on the [[Code for Unplanned Encounters at Sea]].<ref name="Western Pacific Naval Symposium in China agree to maritime code of conduct">{{cite news|title=Member nations of Western Pacific Naval Symposium in China agree to maritime code of conduct|url=http://www.abc.net.au/news/2014-04-22/an-asia-pacific-nations-agree-to-maritime-accord/5405104|accessdate=16 May 2015|work=ABC News|date=23 April 2014}}</ref>
==References== {{Reflist}}
==External links==
{{Foreignrelations-stub}}
[[Category:Conferences]] [[Category:Pacific Ocean]] [[Category:Navies]] [[Category:Diplomatic conferences]]

[[File:Sierra de los Caracoles wind farm.JPG|thumb|right|150px|Sierra de los Caracoles wind farm.]]
'''Wind power in Uruguay''' generates a rapidly growing proportion of the country's [[electricity]] mix.<ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.theguardian.com/environment/2015/dec/03/uruguay-makes-dramatic-shift-to-nearly-95-clean-energy |title=Uruguay makes dramatic shift to nearly 95% electricity from clean energy|publisher=[[The Guardian]] |date=3 December 2015}}</ref> Overall, the majority of Uruguayan electricity generation is derived from hydroelectric sources.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.cia.gov/library/publications/the-world-factbook/geos/uy.html|title=The World Factbook — Central Intelligence Agency|website=www.cia.gov|language=en|access-date=2017-10-03}}</ref>
In 2016, the country’s total installed wind power capacity surpassed 1,000 MW.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.energynews.es/english/uruguay-reached-1000-mw-in-wind-power/|title=Uruguay has reached 1,000 MW in wind power - www.energynews.es|date=2016-10-21|work=www.energynews.es|access-date=2017-10-03|language=es-ES}}</ref> As of 2016, this figure comprised 17 percent of the country’s overall electricity generation,<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.wri.org/blog/2016/03/how-uruguay-became-wind-power-powerhouse|title=How Uruguay Became a Wind Power Powerhouse {{!}} World Resources Institute|website=www.wri.org|language=en|access-date=2017-10-03}}</ref> marking a sudden increase in the overall share from the 2 percent all alternative renewable energy sources made up in 2012.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.cia.gov/library/publications/the-world-factbook/geos/uy.html|title=The World Factbook — Central Intelligence Agency|website=www.cia.gov|language=en|access-date=2017-10-03}}</ref> In July 2018 UTE, the country's power plants and transmission administrator, announced that record electricity demand was being met entirely by renewable sources, of which wind power comprised 34 percent.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.bnamericas.com/en/news/electricpower/utes-investment-plan-made-it-possible-to-cover-the-historical-consumption-peak-in-uruguay|title=UTE investments allow historic consumption peak to be covered - BNamericas|date=2018-07-25|work=BNamericas|access-date=2018-12-02|language=en}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.xinhuanet.com/english/2018-07/25/c_137347180.htm|title=Uruguay's record power demand completely covered by renewable energies - Xinhua {{!}} English.news.cn|website=www.xinhuanet.com|access-date=2018-12-02}}</ref>
The national government has supported this nascent but fast-moving wind power transformation by providing a policy environment of incentives like [[Feed-in tariff|feed-in tariffs]] and utility-scale bidding.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.wri.org/blog/2016/03/how-uruguay-became-wind-power-powerhouse|title=How Uruguay Became a Wind Power Powerhouse {{!}} World Resources Institute|website=www.wri.org|language=en|access-date=2017-10-03}}</ref> The former helped incentivize small-scale installations, while the latter enabled large-scale projects.
== Background == In 2008, the Uruguayan government set a target of 15% joint participation in the national electricity grid by a number of alternative renewable sources, namely biomass, wind power, and mini-hydro.<ref name=":1">{{Cite web|url=http://www.irena.org/DocumentDownloads/Publications/IRENA_RE_Latin_America_Policies_2015_Country_Uruguay.pdf|title=Renewable Energy Policy Brief: Uruguay|last=|first=|date=|website=IRENA|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=}}</ref> Wind power alone far surpassed that proportion in the several years following the setting of that goal. Electricity generation auctions, first put forward in 2006, have been a primary vehicle for larger-scale deployment of mini-hydro and wind power deployment over the past decade.<ref name=":1" />
Some analysts have credited Uruguay's ability to leverage [[United Nations Development Programme|UNDP]] funding to create reliable policy frameworks that would eventually encourage greater standalone private investment in the sector.<ref name=":0">{{Cite web|url=http://www.wri.org/blog/2016/03/how-uruguay-became-wind-power-powerhouse|title=How Uruguay Became a Wind Power Powerhouse {{!}} World Resources Institute|website=www.wri.org|language=en|access-date=2017-10-03}}</ref>
== Wind power in regional electricity trade == Its proximity to [[Argentina]] and [[Brazil]] make for relatively easy electricity trade between the countries, and in 2016 Uruguay began exporting excess wind power generation to neighboring Argentina. The two countries' state-operated utilities had previously sold electricity bilaterally, but the 2016 wind power sales marked the first Uruguayan-Argentine electricity trade between private companies.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.windpowermonthly.com/article/1395152/uruguay-export-wind-energy-argentina|title=Uruguay to Export Wind Energy to Argentina|last=|first=|date=|website=Wind Power Monthly|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=10/2/2017}}</ref> Meanwhile, along the [[Brazil–Uruguay border|Uruguayan border with Brazil]], wind power projects are being approached through a binational partnership with Brazilian utility [[Eletrobras]].<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.wri.org/blog/2016/03/how-uruguay-became-wind-power-powerhouse|title=How Uruguay Became a Wind Power Powerhouse {{!}} World Resources Institute|website=www.wri.org|language=en|access-date=2017-10-03}}</ref>
==Wind farms== [[File:Windmills in northern Uruguay 2.jpg|thumb|Wind turbines in Tacuarembó Department]] There are about 30 wind farms in Uruguay:<ref>[http://www.thewindpower.net/country_windfarms_en_63_uruguay.php Uruguayan windfarms]</ref> * Peralta wind farm (Tacuarembó Department)<ref>[http://www.peraltawind.com/web/en/peralta-i-ii-largest-wind-farm-uruguay Peralta Project]</ref> * Sierra de los Caracoles (Maldonado Department)<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.produccionnacional.com.uy/sierra-de-los-caracoles-3/ |title=Siera de los Caracoles Wind Farm|accessdate=17 December 2016|publisher=Producción Nacional}} {{es icon}}</ref> * Libertad (San José Department)<ref name="negocio"/> * Valentines (Treinta y Tres Department)<ref name="negocio">{{cite web |url=http://www.elpais.com.uy/que-pasa/negocio-viento-energia-eolica-cambio.html |title=Wind is business|date=17 December 2016|publisher=[[El País (Uruguay)|EL PAIS]] }} {{es icon}}</ref>
==See also== * [[Energy in Uruguay]] * [[Electricity sector in Uruguay]] * [[Renewable energy in Uruguay]] * [[Wind power by country]] * ==References== {{reflist||group=|refs=References}} ==External links== {{commonscat}} * [http://www.energiaeolica.gub.uy/ Wind power in Uruguay] - official website
{{Wind power by country}}

revision.comment: Removed reference to 1996 Hotdog of 1996ft, no reference or evidence
revision.text:
[[File:60m Hot Dog Akasaka Aug4 06.jpeg|thumb|The August 2006 record-setting world's longest hot dog, at 60 meters]] The current '''world's longest meat hot dog''' record holder measured {{convert|203.8|m|ft}} and was manufactured by [[Novex]] of Paraguay in 2011. [[Sara Lee Corp.]] made a [[hot dog]], {{convert|1996|ft|m}} long, in commemoration of the [[1996 Summer Olympics]] in [[Atlanta]]. ''[[Guinness World Records]]'' does not reflect this record in any of its publications as of 2006. Speculation surrounding the 1996-foot record is that although the hot dog was most likely continuous, the bun (an integral part of the hot dog unit) was not. Since October 2017 the town [[Flensburg]], in Germany claimed to have manufactured the World's longest hot dog with {{convert|218|m|ft}}.
==Current world records == On July 15, 2011, a hot dog measuring {{convert|203.8|m|ft}} and weighing approximately {{convert|120|kg|lb}} was made by Ochsi to obtain the world record. The [[hot dog bun]] weighed approximately {{convert|150|kg|lb}} and was made by Myriam Products. International media were on hand, and supporting documents have been verified by Johanna Hessling, of Guinness. The hot dog was made as the central part of a media event surrounding the 2011 Expo in Asuncion, Paraguay. After the official measurement, the hot dog was cut up and eaten by those present.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.abc.com.py/nota/paraguay-tiene-el-record-guiness-con-un-pancho-de-203-80-metros/|title=Paraguay tiene el récord Guinness con un pancho de 203,80 metros|author=ABC Color|publisher=|accessdate=30 September 2014}}</ref>
On October 3, 2017 was by local authorities in Flensburg on the [[pier|seabridge]] of the suburb [[Glücksburg]] a U-shaped hot dog measured with {{convert|218.7|m|ft}}. After the official measurement, the hot dog was also cut up and eaten by those present.<ref>[[Schleswig-Holsteinischer Zeitungsverlag]]: [https://www.shz.de/lokales/flensburger-tageblatt/der-weltrekord-steht-id17993121.html Der Weltrekord steht], published and access: October 4, 2017 and [http://www.n-tv.de/mediathek/videos/panorama/Rekordjaeger-bauen-218-Meter-langen-Hotdog-article20064731.html In Glücksburg geht's um die WurstRekordjäger bauen 218 Meter langen Hotdog], published and access: October 4, 2017 and [http://www.ndr.de/nachrichten/schleswig-holstein/Gluecksburg-feiert-mit-dem-laengsten-Hotdog,hotdog120.html Glücksburg feiert mit dem längsten Hotdog], published October 3, 2017; access: October 4, 2017</ref>
==Previous world records== [[Image:World's longest hot dog.jpg|thumb|244px|right|A previous world's longest hot dog (July 15, 2005).]] * In 2001, a hot dog and bun measuring {{convert|4.65|m|ft}} was made in Pennsylvania to obtain the world record. {{Citation needed|date=November 2008}} * On July 2, 2003, a hot dog {{convert|16.1|ft|m}} was made by Vienna Beef and Rosen's Bakery for the Taste of Chicago, in celebration of National Hot Dog Month, to obtain the world record.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.tagrestaurants.com/media_7_3.html |title=Media |publisher=Tag Restaurants |date=2003-07-02 |accessdate=2011-10-22 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20111030080243/http://tagrestaurants.com/media_7_3.html |archivedate=2011-10-30 |df= }}</ref> * On October 18, 2003, a hot dog and bun measuring {{convert|37|ft|2|in|m}} was made by students from the University of Pretoria and displayed at the Sonop Hostel, Pretoria, South Africa, to obtain the world record.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.prnewswire.com/cgi-bin/stories.pl?ACCT=109&STORY=/www/story/07-01-2004/0002204000&EDATE= |title=Vienna(R) Beef Breaks Record at Taste of Chicago for World's Longest Hot Dog, Measuring a Whopping 37 Feet, 2 Inches |location=Chicago, Illinois |publisher=Prnewswire.com |date= |accessdate=2011-10-22}}</ref> * On July 1, 2004, a hot dog and bun measuring {{convert|37.2|ft|m}} was made by Vienna Beef and Rosen's Bakery for the Taste of Chicago, in celebration of National Hot Dog Month, to obtain the world record. The bun used more than 200,000 poppy seeds.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://abclocal.go.com/wls/story?section=News&id=1805816|title=abc7chicago.com - ABC7 WLS Chicago and Chicago News|work=ABC7 Chicago|accessdate=30 September 2014}}</ref> * On July 15, 2005, a hot dog and bun measuring {{convert|50|ft|7|in|m}} was made for the Great American Hot Dog Festival by Jamie Coyne in Columbus, OH.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.prleap.com/pr/22014/ |title=Great American Hot Dog Festival attains Worlds Longest Hot Dog record of 50’ 7 |publisher=Prleap.com |date=2005-12-31 |accessdate=2011-10-22}}</ref> * On August 14, 2005, a hot dog and bun measuring {{convert|57.5|ft|m}} was made by Conshohocken Bakery and Berks Meat Packing for the 20th Annual Corvettes for Kids fundraiser at Bally (USA) to obtain the world record.<ref>[https://web.archive.org/web/20160303233034/http://www.guinnessworldrecords.com/content_pages/record.asp?recordid=53589O ]</ref> * On February 20, 2006, a hot dog and bun measuring {{convert|20|m|ft}} was made by the Department of Sport and Recreation of WA at the Curtin University in Perth to obtain the world record. It required {{convert|25|lb|kg|abbr=off}} of sausage meat, {{convert|33|kg|lb|abbr=off}} of dough, {{convert|10|L|USqt|abbr=off}} of tomato sauce and mustard, and "enough onions to fill a Honda Civic."<ref>[http://www.abc.net.au/perth/stories/s1580171.htm ] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20061016060014/http://www.abc.net.au/perth/stories/s1580171.htm |date=October 16, 2006 }}</ref> * On July 6, 2006, a hot dog and bun measuring {{convert|104.75|ft|m}} was made by the Hill Meat Company of Pendleton, OR and Franz Family Bakeries of Portland, OR. The hot dog was made as the central part of a media event surrounding the 100th anniversary of [[Franz Family Bakeries]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.usbakery.com |title=Home | Franz Family Bakeries |publisher=Usbakery.com |date= |accessdate=2011-10-22}}</ref> * On August 4, 2006, a hot dog measuring {{convert|60|m|ft|sigfig=3}} in a bun measuring {{convert|60.3|m|ft|sigfig=3}} was made by the Shizuoka Meat Producers of Shizuoka, Japan and the [[:ja:全日本パン協同組合連合会|All-Japan Bread Association]] to obtain the world record. International media were on hand, and supporting documents have been verified by Guinness. The hot dog was made as the central part of a media event surrounding the 50th anniversary of the [[:ja:全日本パン協同組合連合会|All-Japan Bread Association]]. The wiener was made offsite at the Shizuoka plant prior to the day, and it was then cooked along with the bread in a ballroom at the [[Akasaka Prince Hotel]] in [[Akasaka, Tokyo|Akasaka]], [[Tokyo]], [[Japan]]. After the official measurement, the hot dog was cut up and eaten by those present.[https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=vhJlmerwRNE][https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=E1H1XvKRzH4][https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=EOaqNrkfDoI][https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=vDPJD-df7E4]
==Technical challenges== Creating a long hot dog is not much of a feat. This is because the hot dog is structurally quite sound, and remarkably flexible. In the August 2006 record breaking attempt, the hot dog was manufactured by Shizuoka Meat Producers, and wound into a large plastic barrel which was easily transported inside a delivery van.
The limiting factor for breaking this type of record is the bun. The bun, in order to remain in one continuous unit, needs to be baked in its final form. For the All-Japan Bread Association, this meant the connection of the longest conveyor belt possible with the equipment available to them. The dough was assembled in half-meter sections, then pressed together to create a longer tube of dough, which was then fed through the ovens via conveyor, and carried away from the ovens by another conveyor. The key was to make sure that the already-cooked bun did not move at a faster rate than the bun behind it because this would cause the bun to pull apart. The wiener was fed through the oven at the same time to cook it. There also needed to be space outside the oven to store the bun and wiener until the entire bun had been baked. To allow for enough room for this to happen, the ovens and prep area were set up outside the ballroom of the [[Akasaka Prince Hotel]] on the loading dock, and the bun and wiener were fed into the ballroom along the conveyor as they exited the oven.
Upon completion, the bun was sliced down the middle by bakers, and spectators were asked to don rubber gloves and first lift the wiener in one piece for photos, and then insert it into the bun. After being topped with mustard and ketchup, the completed hot dog was lifted by the assembled spectators {{convert|30|cm|in}} off the conveyor for photos. Finally, the official measurement was completed, and the wiener was {{convert|60|m|ft|sigfig=3}} in length, with the bun coming in at {{convert|60.3|m|ft|sigfig=3}} in length. After photos and video of the official measurement were completed, the hot dog was cut into sections and the assembled spectators each had a piece. However, this only used about {{convert|8|m|ft}} of the hot dog.
==References== {{portal|Food}} {{reflist}}
{{Hot dogs}}
[[Category:World records]] [[Category:Hot dogs]]

The '''World Curling Rankings''' system is designed to track and list the amount of success achieved by each member association of the [[World Curling Federation]] (WCF) in a given curling season. The system, which was implemented in December 2006, is similar to the [[FIFA World Rankings|ranking system]] used by [[FIFA]]. The events taken into account when calculating each nation's score include the [[Curling at the Winter Olympics|Winter Olympics]], the [[World Curling Championships]], the [[European Curling Championships]], and the [[Pacific Curling Championships]]. The system was developed by [[Patrick Hürlimann]], who is a former [[List of Olympic medalists in curling|Olympic champion]] and was the vice president of the WCF from 2010 to 2012. ==Method of calculation== The points are calculated for each nation based on performance during the last six curling seasons. Results in seasons prior to the current season are scaled by the following factors: {| class="wikitable" style="font-weight:bold; text-align:center" |- |align=left bgcolor=#efefef| Years prior to current season ||width=20| 0 ||width=20| 1 ||width=20| 2 ||width=20| 3 ||width=20| 4 ||width=20| 5 |- |align=left bgcolor=#efefef| Scaling factor ||width=20| 100% ||width=20| 80% ||width=20| 60% ||width=20| 40% ||width=20| 30% ||width=20| 20% |} ===Points distribution=== Points are allocated based on the final rankings of each nation at an eligible event. ====International events==== The points distributions are given for each event as follows: {| class="wikitable" style="font-weight:bold; text-align:center" |+Winter Olympic Games |- |align=left bgcolor=#efefef| Final rank ||width=20| 1 ||width=20| 2 ||width=20| 3 ||width=20| 4 ||width=20| 5 ||width=20| 6 ||width=20| 7 ||width=20| 8 ||width=20| 9 ||width=20| 10 ||width=20| 11 ||width=20| 12 |- |align=left bgcolor=#efefef| Points ||width=20| 480 ||width=20| 400 ||width=20| 360 ||width=20| 320 ||width=20| 280 ||width=20| 240 ||width=20| 200 ||width=20| 180 ||width=20| 160 ||width=20| 140 ||width=20| 120 ||width=20| 100 |} {| class="wikitable" style="font-weight:bold; text-align:center" |+World Curling Championships |- |align=left bgcolor=#efefef| Final rank ||width=20| 1 ||width=20| 2 ||width=20| 3 ||width=20| 4 ||width=20| 5 ||width=20| 6 ||width=20| 7 ||width=20| 8 ||width=20| 9 ||width=20| 10 ||width=20| 11 ||width=20| 12 |- |align=left bgcolor=#efefef| Points ||width=20| 240 ||width=20| 200 ||width=20| 180 ||width=20| 160 ||width=20| 140 ||width=20| 120 ||width=20| 100 ||width=20| 90 ||width=20| 80 ||width=20| 70 ||width=20| 60 ||width=20| 50 |} ====Regional events==== All nations that qualify for the World Curling Championships receive 50 points, regardless of final ranking in regional events, if applicable. Nations in the European or Pacific Curling Championships that do not qualify for the World Championships receive less than 50 points. Based on their final ranking in the tournament, nations receive 49 or fewer points, in decrements of 1 point. ==Rankings== ===Men=== {| class="wikitable" style="text-align:center;" |- ! colspan="4" |Final rankings for the [[2016–17 curling season|2016–17 season]], as of February 14 2018{{Cite news|url=http://www.worldcurling.org/worldrankings|title=World Curling Federation - World Rankings|work=World Curling Federation|access-date=2018-02-14|language=en}} |- !width="60"|Current
